transcripts.text: Sean, you were in the earthquake.
I was.
Did you pray?
Not during the earthquake.  I can't say I did, no.
What size earthquake would cause you to pray?  An 8.5?

You know, the one we had back in, I think it was the Whittier quake, kind of woke me up back when I was a kid.  That one was a little scary.  But other than that, they're kind of fun, I think.  Of course, that doesn't take away from the damage and all the terrible stuff that they bring to, you know, the victims of them, you know.
So you believe in God's existence?  Absolutely, yeah.  Do you think there's an afterlife?
I already said yeah, I think so to that.  You do?  I couldn't tell you what the answer is because I don't know the answer myself, but I believe so, yeah.
You think there's a heaven and a hell?
Sure.
Who goes to heaven and who goes to hell?
Well, you know, that comes down to you and your beliefs, doesn't it?
Well, not really.  If I go to court, my beliefs have got nothing to do with what the judge gives me.  What's set in the law is what's going to happen.  Okay.
If that's what you believe, that's true.  There you go.

No, that's not true because, oh, I believe that.  My beliefs don't change anything.  If I believe the sun is square or it's made of ice and it comes out at night, it doesn't change reality.  It's true for you.  It is not.  That's delusional.
There's people that identify as a fish or a chair or something these days.
Years ago, they would have been locked up for that.  Nowadays, they accept it.
Now that's the norm.
So if heaven exists, are you going there?  Are you a good person?
Oh, you know, I hope I'll be forgiven for my sins when the time's come, sure.
So you have sinned?
Of course, haven't you?
Yeah, so you've lied and stolen?  Sure.  The way to know if you're going to make it to heaven is just look at the Ten Commandments.  Third Commandment.
I've probably broken all of them.
So you've murdered somebody?
Well, I was in the military 22 years.
That's not murder.  That's, you know, defending a country.
It depends on how you look at it, you know.  Man's law or God's law, come on.  We could go round and round all day long on this stuff, you know.
Have you ever used God's name in vain?  Absolutely.
My buddy straightened me out on that one the other day.
Would you use your mother's name as a cuss word?
My mother's name, like directly?  I can't, nah.
Because that would dishonor her.
In Italian they do it.
According to the Old Testament, blasphemy is so serious it's punishable by death.  Now, Jesus said whoever looks...
We don't live under the Old Testament anymore, isn't it?

Well, that law is still standing.  It's eternal.  It's written in stone.  Now, Jesus said if you look at a woman and lust for her, you commit adultery with her in your heart.  Have you ever looked at a woman with lust?
Sure.
Have you had sex before marriage or after marriage?
Yeah, sure.

So, Sean, I'm not judging you, but you've just told me... Just like the Bible says, all liars are their part in the lake of fire.  So that law is eternal.  It's written in stone.  It's written on our hearts via the conscience.  So we're without excuse.  And so on Judgment Day, if you're condemned for your sins, does that concern you that you're going to end up in hell?
You know, if that's where it ends up going, then I probably deserve it.
Well, you deserve it, but you don't have to go there because the Bible says God's rich in mercy.  Tell me, what did God do for guilty sinners so we wouldn't have to go to hell?
I guess because he loves us, man.  I don't know.
What did he do?
Oh, what did he do?  He gave us his son, man.  He's a story.  Come on.  Do you want me to recount it for you?  Yes, please.  Recount it.  It's a good history.  I couldn't tell you.

It's the gospel.  Let me recount it for you very briefly and get your thoughts on it.  You and I broke God's law, the Ten Commandments.  They're called the moral law.  Jesus paid the fine.  That's what happened on the cross.  That's why he cried out, it is finished.  In other words, the debt has been paid.  If you're in court, even though you're guilty, if someone pays you a fine, the judge can legally let you go.  He can say, Sean, you've got a stack of speeding fines.  Someone's paid them.  You're out of here, even though you're guilty.  You can do that, which is legal and just.  Well, God can legally dismiss your case, forgive your sins, commute your death sentence because of what Jesus did on the cross and still do that, which is just and right.  Beautiful.  because of the death and resurrection of Christ.  Yeah, look, a parachute is a beautiful thing, but if you're not wearing it, it's not going to help you.
Sure, there you go.

What I'm saying to you, Sean, is that the way to be saved is to repent of your sins, confess and forsake them, and trust in Jesus like you trust a parachute.  Trust in Christ alone.  Repent of your sins.  Does this make sense, what I'm saying?
It sure does, but, you know, you don't know where I'm at.  I appreciate the message.
Yeah, well, I do hope you'll think about it.  I don't know where you're at, but wearing a T-shirt like that gives me kind of a clue.
I might have just had a weird day.  I grabbed a shirt out of the closet.
So, what do you think about what we talked about?
I do.  I think about it all the time.
Do you have a Bible at home?
Absolutely, yeah.
When did you last read it, Sean?
What is today?  Saturday?  Six days ago.
So, you were at church?
I don't think I went last week.

So this is your eternity.  So I trust that you'll give some serious thought to what we talked about.  And remember the words of Jesus, what shall it profit a man if he gains the whole world and loses his own soul?  Hey, thanks for talking to me, Sean.  I appreciate it.
Absolutely.  Have a good day, man.  Thank you.
